RT @nataliexdean: The % vaccine breakthroughs in a population depends on: - Vaccine efficacy - Amt of virus circulating - Length of time si

@davidmanheim @dylanbgeorge @iserp_columbia Similar to Laurie's question, I think having ongoing capabilities to analyze and understand data regularly will help us to find opportunities for improvement. e.g. analysis of volume of infected travelers w/ SARS-CoV-2 revealed substantial underascertainment early in pandemic.
Again, these events are under investigation and we will learn more from the experts. If confirmed, the events will still be rare. But one in a million is unlikely to be the final tally. 5/5

Third, time. FDA said it was 1-2 weeks to onset. People who have received doses within that time would not normally be considered in the denominator either. On Mar 26 there were 2.7M JJ doses administered. (Not exactly 2 wks but closest date I could find.) 4/
Second, the denominator. All of the cases in US have been in women ages 18-48. It is reasonable to ask whether the denominator should reflect that. The expert committee will consider this. 3/
@C_R_Watson First, the numerator. Now that awareness has been raised, more cases may be reported. 2/ https://t.co/zJrlXHv54q

One in a million will not be the final estimate for the unconfirmed JJ events and I think we should be cautious in citing it. The incidence will surely be rare, but @C_R_Watson and I wrote about biases in estimating mortality last Feb, and similar issues are in play here 1/

"Many reports compare the total reported number of deaths with the overall reported number of cases. This is, intuitively, the fraction of people who die from the disease. But early in an outbreak, this type of calculation is often misleading." (2020) https://t.co/zJrlXHv54q

Join us at 1230 ET! https://t.co/oxhoyvjW4u https://t.co/tPHaaQD87z

The bottom line for individuals is that if you are not fully vax or recently recovered you should still be taking all the usual precautions to reduce risk. That is what I am doing. But big picture, we are in a better position than if we were seeing these trends last fall. 7/7

Working against us is the variants, esp B117 which is now common and spreads more easily. This set us on a tougher course than we may have otherwise faced at this point, but the vaccines work well against B117 so distributing them as fast as possible still top priority. 6/

And now that many people at highest risk of severe illness are vaccinated, we can expect hospitalizations and deaths to be lower relative to case burden. Thats another bit of good news, though I would still like to see cases come down too. 5/

But at national level, unlike previous upticks, we now have vax coverage at ~16% and each day we distribute ~3M doses which will further reduce risk, day over day. This is on top of estimated 25-30% pop immunity from prior infection. 4/

Yet some states are resurging. MI and NJ are at ~50 cases per 100,000 per day and hosp rising too. Risk in those states is high, and leaders should intervene by closing high risk settings and accelerating vaccination. Fed govt could help by sending extra vax coming online. 3/

Many states are doing quite well. I would like to see cases fall below 20 cases per 100,000 per day as a first goal and 10 as a second goal (and then the lower the better). By that measure, we are doing ok: 35 states are at or below 20 and 12 are below 10. 2/
Cases are on the rise in many states. How worried am I? I am concerned, but not as much as I would have been 6 months ago with these trends. Short thread. 1/

Last April, @60Minutes aired a story featuring @dylanbgeorge about the need for an outbreak forecasting center. Today they aired an update - the American Rescue Plan has $500M for the forecasting center + public health data modernization. https://t.co/6dAYEl1vsZ

Tomorrow the UK is taking a small step toward reopening after months of stay at home restrictions. The UK has one of highest vaccination rates in the world (mostly first doses) so will be interesting to see whether transmission remains low. I very much hope it's smooth sailing. https://t.co/F95cCT1FMc

There is so much epi data we don't have that would be useful right now. Data on reinfection, including time from first infection and severity; incidence by age at subnational level; cluster investigations from variant cases; more on pediatric infections and school reopening.

Two new papers find large covid clusters in fitness facilities - including some examples in Hawaii where every single class attendee was infected. In Chicago, case study, 68%. Indoor gyms are going to be a no for me for a while yet. https://t.co/5SGaGY46vl https://t.co/aEBA9kcv6g

For what its worth I continue to be encouraged by trends in cases, hosp and deaths. May be ups and downs ahead but every day we are administering ~2M vaccines. Will protect recipients and slow transmission. Phased reopening best, starting with lower risk activities. Keep masks.
